docs.abstract: Backdrop column offers photos of rebots designed at MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory; robots are built to 'interact intelligently with people, the environment, and each other'; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Jobs like stacking heavy boxes or fixing power lines can be dangerous, so why not give some of that work to robots? That's part of the motivation behind the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, known as Csail, at M.I.T. The lab's goal is to design robots that ''interact intelligently with people, the environment and each other'' and to create ''societal benefits through applications in homes, fields, oceans and outer space.'' Students and staff members of the Robot Locomotion Group, a part of Csail, use sophisticated formulas and materials, along with old-fashioned tools like pliers, wire and scissors, to create their robots -- which at times seem almost alive.

docs.abstract: Jeffrey Marlow, California Institute of Technology graduate student, blogs about his deep-ocean exploration of micro-organisms off Oregon coast; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Sunday, Aug. 8 Saturday night, long after the sun had gone down but long before the day's final sample had been processed, I wandered out to Atlantis' bow with a steaming mug of peppermint tea. Hearing the waves lap against the boat, feeling the salty breeze, and looking into the expansive blackness, I tried to savor the moment, anticipating the fact that on Sunday, I'd make my first dive on Alvin.
